title: The Invisible Blanket
segmentation: Um, like I've done before.
I'm really honored and glad to be here today.
And my head is spinning from all the great ideas so.
I feel the day started with Jacques and it went into all these topics and now it's ending somewhere a little bit lighter.
Because when I, when I realized that I have to speak, I re read what I actually wrote and basically the main statement was instead of heavy, precious and permanent.
The future of architecture is light, thin and Meryl.
What exactly was it trying to say?
Um, basically this lecture is going to dismantle this statement because what happened in the short time between when I made the statement and now I got a building Commission?
And that statement came out of a practice that I've had over the past couple of years, which was very much focused on installations and performances and exhibition design at the math.
And it all came out of a desire actually to build and to create things in full scale in real life.
And it's slightly ironic because I teach representation and then I realized that my work is extremely anti representational and today were so many beautiful drawings and this was sort of.
There's no drawing I think, or maybe some screenshots in this presentation.
Um?
And just geographically, where to find me?
I'm born here, but actually, you know, haven't spent too much time here in the past years.
I've been mostly in New York for the past six years.
Teaching at Columbia.
Working at the Met and then I'm part of an incubator space at the new ink, which is sort of an incubator based intersection of art and technology.
But right now, because of this Commission, I moved to Vienna temporarily.
And some old classmates of mine took me in Madame Architects, and I'm I'm there right now.
So, so thinking of.
Almost provocative statement that I put out that I don't believe in anymore.
I was thinking how do I?
How can I argue that to myself that this is relevant?
Reality and so, um, so I thought maybe I need to create kind of a guidebook or a set of tools that I can take with me.

It's basically a design book for architects that are used to think of architectures as something permanent and bringing in all this experience I've made creating temporary environments and I would call it tools for show, which is sort of a continuation of another.
Book that I've written as part of my thesis at Columbia, which is called tools for things, and this book was about software news about the history of software and how to access software.

Something very widely accepted, a generic that we just take as a tool, and this was about that most of the time it comes actually from a different discipline and then enters the the sort of area of architecture and becomes part of our discipline.
But those original sort of.
The heritage is still possible, and it actually has effects on how we design and in the end in to how we built this.

Sort of a counter or kind of a different proposal with a similar idea that you kind of look for these tools that we use in exhibition design or in sort of more temporary environments that are that aspects don't feel belong to them or part of their expertise necessarily.
And because this is not existing yet, I'll just walk you through our projects to kind of show you some of the practice that.

I've been developing Anna group them into three different categories because a lot of the projects are very very simple, very cheap, very quickly put together and this is the project actually applied with and the first group is kinda surface category because they're all basically surface surface based.
And this was the.
Invisible blanket in New York City on a rooftop and we basically used six emergency blankets.
I think the total cost of the project was $21 and created and used tape also and created this roof.

That wasn't visible from above, because in New York the rules are painted silver to reflect light, and so a satellite wouldn't, you know, we wouldn't be visible from above from a satellite and you can spot it here in the image from a rooftop that's higher up and sort of created this project.
The pride of its own, but underneath emergency blankets just because of how they are there, Golden.
And actually quite beautiful when they move.
Going to wind and we worked with the flower designer.
You know she did a series of events and she created custom flower arrangements for Ford.
For those events.
Which is something really really also integral to all this practice as we always work with whoever is around all kinds of creative people to just come and contribute.
You know, we start with an idea and through sort of series of events, more and more people start coming in.
Or like I want to do this, I'm going to do that.
Um, this is just a snapshot of during the day.
How many people you know it became a little social space and it was a little bit lower so we had to crawl underneath.
And created a nice.
Community and at night, when the wind would become really strong, it actually got almost like an aquatic quality and started to move and wave and just became sort of this Sir.
Us to look to look at this is another project which you also, so this is a yearly project.
Every year we do at least one of those installations.
This was one or two years earlier where we worked with at the answer.
And so here again, it was a surface simple fabric structure that during the day was kind of a canopy for design market.
We divided our friends to come over and sell their stuff.
And then at night there was this moment of transition where the dancer started interacting with the fabric.
And you know, had a 10 minute performance.
And then she tore this fabric off the roof and it became a piece of cloth.
Thing and she started wearing it and I love this mix of different disciplines because it involved architecture in a way, a roof dance and then also fashion.
And then when I was at the Met, just as we opened the old, Whitney was taken over by building muscle bright.
It most of you know.
Probably it's a it was built in 1966 and 50 years later I'm at the Met.
Took on that building and for the opening of the new basically our renovated version of the building we wanted to mark the building an exterior.
So this idea came up off the inverted red carpet so you know, with met with the Met Gala.
Red carpet has a strong Association.
And this was the idea of kind of more Democratic open version and also the red is sort of the new Med brand like kinda brand color that they want to use this to to sell the building.
So it's sort of broader different aspects of the new 'cause they had gone to a giant rebranding.
They got a new one and this was kind of a visual mark on the building too.
For that purpose, for opening purpose.
But again, it's only a surface.
It's only a very thin layer, and it also is already gone.
That was on.
Gone for a short time.
Another surface, this was a table.
We have some beautiful tables drawing table drop services.

The deal of a table for all ages and people of all sizes that brings them together to draw and we created this custom tools for it and also installed it temporarily in in old with Needham at Briar and I am really glad because they kept it.
Now in the museum they they take it out again for for special events and use it so this one is gone but not completely or it's still.
It's sort of lives on.
A few things.
And then the surface screen is sort of a subcategory of surface.
You know it's just it's a digital surface.
Let's say this was a project that at Emily Harvey Gallery in New York and it was basically like this, a conference and everyone.
Everyone's brain was just like exhausted.

Then afterwards you have drinks were going to have soon, but my day was like I was supposed to organize a conference and I refused because the topic was about criticality criticality and I thought it's not interesting to critique on criticality and so instead.
I created this event where we basically just projected all this move.
Bring lines onto the table.
Where later consume food was served and it was really created.
The choreography of a whole evening of how people came in.
It was completely dark and they only started moving services and then throughout the evening the lights went slightly up and sort of you could actually see other people as well and the food.
And everything, and um, what was nice about that that people thought it was interactive and started to play or wanted to touch the table which it actually.
It was just a simple projection.
And here we took advantage of of our friends my friends insulation in Attic and Allah.
This was action interactive.
One day they had this great projected onto the ground and this is one of the simplest projects.
We basically just brought together a dancer which was Arsenal are those of you who remember Rams.
Banality was kind of a section that combined all the different parts but then it still put the dancers on a separate pedestal instead of really joining them into architecture.
So people were in stages rather than.
Dancing with an architecture so our idea was to bring in a dancer from that other part and just bring him into the actual architecture exhibition and have her perform there.
And you know, going away from surface plinth is another temporary exhibition measure.
It's something that's custom designed to.
So something like just checking how long time, yeah?

Designed to showcase an object and I think that's something that architects don't really like to do because basically the plinth or the base has to disappear and object needs to be shown and it's something I think.

It's a sort of, I think mark we called it content paranoia and I think it's it's this idea that you know we always want to design something for a program that can then develop in our spaces and people can do all these things freely and we were very reluctant to create something extremely specific that should basically disappear underneath the object.
And this is something I feel an exhibition design that I learned that in a way to be very humbled and to just make everything for to carry that object.
Um, this was one.
One person voted for a wedding dress by car Lagerfeld in last year's Model 6 document, Max Manus X Machina show at the Met.
Um?
And then this was another even more simple example where unfinished was a show of 200 different artworks that were all from basically from the Renaissance until today.
That all had some kind of aspect of unfinished Ness about them.
And so if you imagine, if you have a Rembrandt and it Castle and all these different artworks next to each other, each of them has a different light requirement.
Humidity requirement has to hang at a different height, have to be hung in specific different ways.
And you know this is just looks very, very simple, but it's an incredibly complicated architectural project because you have to really engineer this length to carry certain weight.
To have the glass and in a certain angle to certain things at a certain height and so on.
This the sand people are not allowed to step on the sand and you have to kind of take in account not just any educated visitor but also children.
Anybody who would visit visit that museum.

And this is another kind of pin sits at the table, but it's also, you know, a point of that has a lot of technology inside of it, and that acts as a point of exchange, and that is sort of shaped very, very much bye.
Um, it's function, but then you can.
You can introduce some other.
Elements.
And now you know then sort of the third chapter.
If you have surface we have plinth and then there's environment.
This is sort of a glimpse of this project that I talked about that we got commissioned and so how do we?
It's it's kind of a Community Event Center in Lower Austria.
It's an extension to an existing building.
But it's a challenge.
You know.
How do you bring all these ideas and all this expertise of that for Marilyn to something that has to be permanent by definition and heavy?
I don't have a solution yet.
I'm working on it.
I would love to present it tonight, but I would also love to put, you know, to put together this, this Handbook Handbook and really analyze those different strategies.
I mean, now I sort of showed my own work, but obviously there's like a wealth of examples out there that you can use and understand how sort of.
This type of temporality or this type of?
Lightness can can be used in architecture and we have some ideas.
I'm here.
You see the suggestion of the Golden roof.
What if?
What if the roof would be fabric and you could exchange it?
As you know, just sort of this lattice on the side that actually it's a bit like Miller said.
If it's lazy, it's trying to be lazy architecture where things would change or be defined by.
You know, by nature or by something outside of itself.
So this is where we are in the design right now, it's very.
Simple building, but hopefully we can test some of those thesis there.
Thank you.
